unnormalised: Okay folks, let’s talk Rental Agreements! You wouldn't eat Biryani without raita, right? Same goes for renting in India – don't even *think* about doing it without a solid rental agreement.
normalised: Okay folks, let’s talk Rental Agreements! You wouldn't eat Biryani without raita, right? Same goes for renting in India – don't even think about doing it without a solid rental agreement.

unnormalised: So, you’ve found that perfect 2BHK in Bandra, Mumbai. Awesome! But before you hand over that hefty security deposit (usually like, 2-3 months rent, ugh!), make sure everything is in writing.
normalised: So, you’ve found that perfect two B H K in Bandra, Mumbai. Awesome! But before you hand over that hefty security deposit (usually like, two to three months rent, ugh!), make sure everything is in writing.

unnormalised: Think about it: what if the landlord, Mr. Sharma, suddenly decides to increase the rent by Rs. 5000 after only 6 months? Or what if your neighbour, Priya, complains incessantly about your late-night Bollywood music sessions? A rental agreement is your shield!
normalised: Think about it: what if the landlord, Mister Sharma, suddenly decides to increase the rent by rupees five thousand after only six months? Or what if your neighbour, Priya, complains incessantly about your late-night Bollywood music sessions? A rental agreement is your shield!

unnormalised: What should it cover? Obvious stuff like the monthly rent (Rs. X), security deposit amount, duration of the lease (usually 11 months to avoid registration hassles), and late payment penalties. But also, things like who’s responsible for repairs (like a leaky tap or a broken AC), pet policies (important if you have a furry friend!), and termination clauses.
normalised: What should it cover? Obvious stuff like the monthly rent (rupees X), security deposit amount, duration of the lease (usually eleven months to avoid registration hassles), and late payment penalties. But also, things like who’s responsible for repairs (like a leaky tap or a broken A C), pet policies (important if you have a furry friend!), and termination clauses.

unnormalised: Make sure it specifies when the landlord can visit (with prior notice, of course!), and what happens when you want to renew the agreement. And PLEASE, get it notarized. That small extra cost (around Rs. 500-1000) is worth it for the added legal weight.
normalised: Make sure it specifies when the landlord can visit (with prior notice, of course!), and what happens when you want to renew the agreement. And PLEASE, get it notarized. That small extra cost (around rupees five hundred to one thousand) is worth it for the added legal weight.

unnormalised: Remember, a well-drafted rental agreement can save you a LOT of headaches down the line. Think of it as your Onam Sadhya of peace of mind! Don't skimp on this crucial step. Good luck finding your dream rental!
